title: Install issues on macOS - "error: no member named 'to_string' in namespace"
body_html:
Currently trying to setup my dev environment to work on #3185 and had some errors come from some C++ headers.

macOS Sierra: Version 10.12.6
Python version: 3.5

  • git clone --recursive git@github.com:pytorch/pytorch.git
  • mkvirtualenv pytorch-dev -p /usr/local/bin/python3.5
  • export NO_CUDA=1 to my .bash_profile & source it
  • pip install numpy pyyaml setuptools cmake cffi
  • python setup.py build develop

Do I need conda for this? Or should I still be able to do it with a virtualenv?

Output:

/pytorch/torch/lib/ATen/../ATen/Half.h:24:17: error: implicit instantiation of undefined template
      'std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> >'
    std::string msg = "value cannot be converted to type ";
                ^
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/../include/c++/v1/iosfwd:193:33: note: template is declared here
    class _LIBCPP_TYPE_VIS_ONLY basic_string;
                                ^
In file included from /Users/freddiev4/Documents/opensource/pytorch/torch/lib/ATen/Context.cpp:1:
In file included from /Users/freddiev4/Documents/opensource/pytorch/torch/lib/ATen/Context.h:7:
In file included from /Users/freddiev4/Documents/opensource/pytorch/torch/lib/build/ATen/ATen/Type.h:9:
/Users/freddiev4/Documents/opensource/pytorch/torch/lib/ATen/../ATen/Half.h:27:17: error: no member named 'to_string' in namespace
      'std'
    msg += std::to_string(f);
           ~~~~~^
[ 12%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/ATen.dir/Scalar.cpp.o

Followed by warnings

10 warnings generated.
19 warnings generated.
10 warnings generated.
make[1]: *** [CMakeFiles/ATen.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [all] Error 2

It looks like there were some other issues opened for this/related stuff previously like #948

If there's any other useful info I can provide, let me know 🙂

(also I came across this really nice read while searching around on Google for a solution http://pytorch.org/2017/05/11/Internals.html)

macOS Sierra: Version 10.12.6

export NO_CUDA=1 to my .bash_profile & source it

body:
Currently trying to setup my dev environment to work on https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/3185 and had some errors come from some C++ headers.

macOS Sierra: Version 10.12.6
Python version: 3.5

- `git clone --recursive git@github.com:pytorch/pytorch.git`
- `mkvirtualenv pytorch-dev -p /usr/local/bin/python3.5`
- `export NO_CUDA=1` to my `.bash_profile` & source it
- `pip install numpy pyyaml setuptools cmake cffi`
- `python setup.py build develop`

Do I _need_ conda for this? Or should I still be able to do it with a virtualenv?

**Output:**
```
/pytorch/torch/lib/ATen/../ATen/Half.h:24:17: error: implicit instantiation of undefined template
      'std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> >'
    std::string msg = "value cannot be converted to type ";
                ^
/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/usr/bin/../include/c++/v1/iosfwd:193:33: note: template is declared here
    class _LIBCPP_TYPE_VIS_ONLY basic_string;
                                ^
In file included from /Users/freddiev4/Documents/opensource/pytorch/torch/lib/ATen/Context.cpp:1:
In file included from /Users/freddiev4/Documents/opensource/pytorch/torch/lib/ATen/Context.h:7:
In file included from /Users/freddiev4/Documents/opensource/pytorch/torch/lib/build/ATen/ATen/Type.h:9:
/Users/freddiev4/Documents/opensource/pytorch/torch/lib/ATen/../ATen/Half.h:27:17: error: no member named 'to_string' in namespace
      'std'
    msg += std::to_string(f);
           ~~~~~^
[ 12%] Building CXX object CMakeFiles/ATen.dir/Scalar.cpp.o
```

Followed by warnings

```
10 warnings generated.
19 warnings generated.
10 warnings generated.
make[1]: *** [CMakeFiles/ATen.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [all] Error 2
```

It looks like there were some other issues opened for this/related stuff previously like https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/948

If there's any other useful info I can provide, let me know 🙂 


(also I came across this really nice read while searching around on Google for a solution http://pytorch.org/2017/05/11/Internals.html)
